div.p: II.45. IV.10. Fahrenheit 65 at Sunrise
How art thou fallen from Heaven, O Lucifer, son of the morning! how art thou cut down to the ground, which didst weaken the Nations
Isaiah 14.12.

This Lucifer son of the morning is the dogstar, Sirius. I rose this morning before him, but saw him, about three quarters of an hour high, and then from the eastern corner of Charles’s house I saw the Sun rise at 5.
The Lucifer of this passage of Isaiah denotes also the king of Babylon—but whether Nebuchadnezzar or Belshazzar, is not apparent.

In the 7th chapter of this book of Isaiah is a distinct prophesy that within three-score and five years, Ephraim shall be broken, that it be not a people— Ephraim is the kingdom of Israel—the ten tribes, and the prophet foretells the Assyrian captivity.— The Lord commands Ahaz king of Judah to ask a sign to prove that the confederacy of Ephraim and Syria shall not prevail against Judah— Ahaz refuses to ask a sign, or to tempt the Lord. Whereupon the Lord says he will himself give a sign—and what is the sign?— [“]Behold, a Virgin shall conceive, and bear a Son, and shall call his name Immanuel.” and in the subsequent verses the destruction of both the kingdoms of Israel and of Judah is predicted to happen before this child shall know to refuse the evil and choose the good— The whole prophesy relates to the wars and alliances of the kingdoms of Judah, Israel and Syria in the days of Ahaz—742 years before the birth of Christ— But in the first chapter of Matthew v. 18–23. it is said that the angel of the Lord appearing to Joseph in a dream, announced to him that Mary was with child by the holy Ghost, and the evangelist says all this was done, that this prophesy of Isaiah might be fulfilled. A prophesy to Ahaz king of Judah, announcing the failure of an actual confederacy of Israel and Syria, against Judah, but predicting the impending destruction of both the Jewish kingdoms, is the casket in which is enchased, the birth 700 years after of the Saviour of the world, begotten by the holy ghost upon a woman and son of God the father, from whom and from the son, the same holy ghost is said in the Athanasian creed to proceed— It were an exercise perhaps more curious than profitable to collate all the passages in the old testament which are quoted in the new as prophesies fulfilled by the advent of Jesus Christ— I received a Letter from Nathaniel Frye at Washington 28 August with a Bill of lading for four boxes, one chest and one leather trunk, shipped at Georgetown in the Schooner Forest king, Kelley Master for me. The day slipped away, and left no rembrance behind— I walked up the hill at the approach of Sunset, and rode with Mrs Charles down to the Mount Wollaston House to meet and take home my Son, and his Sons Charles and Henry returning from bathing at the beach— And Charles and his wife spent an Evening hour here— Mary Louisa went to Boston for a riding school lesson.
2. II.45— IV:15. Fahrenheit 76 at Sunrise— Shower-bath—
Wo to the multitude of many people, which make a noise like the noise of the seas; and to the rushing of nations, that make a rushing like the rushing of mighty waters. Isaiah 17.12.

div.p: At the meeting of the Supervisors of the Adams temple, and school fund on the 16th. of last October, it had been voted, that there should be a yearly meeting of the board on the first Monday of September, at 11. O’Clock A.M. at the chamber of the selectmen in the new Granite town Hall. There had usually been a meeting once a year since the decease of my father at my house, but it had not been specially prescribed, and in 1844 had from inadvertence been omitted— The permission of the Selectmen for the use of their chamber had been obtained and the Meeting was held this day. All the members of the board present— Thomas Greenleaf President, Josiah Quincy, George W. Beale, my Son, Charles Francis Adams, and myself. Mr Greenleaf presented the report of the Committee to examine the accounts of the Treasurer John Briesler also Treasurer of the town, which was accepted and ordered to be recorded— Mr Greenleaf communicated also a paper signed by William B. Duggan, Harvey Field, and sundry others addressed to the Selectmen requesting them to call a town meeting to see if the town will take any measures for carrying into execution my father’s purpose of establishing a classical school in this place— One of the Selectmen had put this paper into the hands of Mr Greenleaf as an advisement to the Supervisors— I thought it should be entered on the minutes and a vote should be taken to notify the Selectmen that the Supervisors had no objection to the call of a town meeting, but had no wish for it and were specially desirous, not to encumber the town with any charge whatever, on account of this trust— But my Son and the other members of the board thought that no notice of the paper should be taken of the paper on the minutes, but that it should be returned by Mr Greenleaf to the Selectmen, with a verbal assurance that the Supervisors have no objection to the town meeting, but will take no part in calling it— Mr Greenleaf, alledging his age and infirmities, invited the Supervisors to elect another President, and expressed a wish that I might be chosen, but I pleaded the same disabilities, in at least equal degree—and requested that the consideration of Mr Greenleaf’s proposal should be postponed till the next annual meeting, which was formally moved by Mr Quincy and unanimously voted— About one O’Clock the meeting was dissolved, and I walked home— Mr Greenleaf, Mr Quincy and Mr Beale dined with us together with Mr Lunt, Dr. Woodward and my Son. His wife would not come. I walked up the hill about Sunset, but the Orb buried himself in haze.
3. II.45— IV. Fahrenheit 65 at Sunrise 5.27. Shower bath.

And behold here cometh a chariot of men, with a couple of horsemen— And he answered and said, Babylon is fallen, is fallen; and all the graven images of her gods he hath broken unto the ground. Isaiah 21.9.

Campbell in his philosophy of rhetoric, citing this passage as an example of the best order of words in a sentence says the version should be—Fallen—fallen is Babylon &c—and surely that turn of the phrase, would vastly increase the energy of the thought.— I received this day

list.item: 1. A circular notification from Edward Everett President of Harvard University that a meeting of the Committee of the Board of Overseers to visit the Observatory will be holden on Wednesday the 9th. of this month in No. 5. University Hall at 2 1/2 P.M. The Committee consists of J. Q. Adams, John P Cushing; Abbott Lawrence, J. Ingersoll Bowditch, David Sears, and Robert Treat Paine.

2. A small printed pamphlet 35 pages 12mo. Cannibalism the crime prohibited in the 9th chapter of Genesis, by John W. Browne— A curious dissertation to prove that the denunciation to Noah, whoso sheddeth man’s blood, by man shall his blood be shed, refers not to murder, but to the eating of human flesh— It is an indirect argument against Capital punishment.

3. A Letter from Edwin Hess?, Georgetown Missouri 13. August 1846. requesting me to prepare for him two Lectures, one upon Education, and the other upon reading and to send him the Report of the Commissioners of Patents for the year 1846.

4. A Letter from E S. Young, corresponding Secretary of the Pleasant Hill Literary Society—Farmer’s College, Hamilton County Ohio—24. August 1846. informing me that I have been elected an honorary member of that Society— There is no such College as Farmer’s College of Hamilton County Ohio, in the list of American Colleges in the American Almanac— Mr Young’s Letter is Postmarked Cary’s Academy, O— and there is such a Post-Office in Hamilton County, Ohio— Cary’s Academy has doubtless expanded into Farmer’s College and Pleasant Hill Literary Society has swollen with it.
5. A Letter from Anne E Carroll, Baltimore 29. August 1846. proposing to establish in that City a monthly periodical, and inviting contributions to it from me.

6. A Letter from David Myerle Washington 28 August 1826, concerning a claim of his against the United States—with copy of a Letter to him from W. Paulding once Secretary of the Navy, and a printed Report to H.R.U.S. and Bill by I. E Holmes from the Committee of Naval affairs in its favour 17. June 1846.

7. A Letter from Asa Whitney New-York 1 September 1846. concerning his project for a rail-road from Lake Michigan to the Pacific Ocean—enclosing the report of the Committee of U.S. Senate, made 31. July 1846. by Sidney Breese a Senator from Illinois with a Bill setting apart public Lands for the construction of this Rail-road.

div.p: Continued to morrow—my Son came witha member of the 28th. Congress 2. Session— I rode this afternoon with my two daughters.
4. I.50— IV. Fahrenheit 70 at Sun rise 5.28. Shower bath

But the word of the Lord was unto them, precept upon precept, precept upon precept, line upon line, line upon line, here a little and there a little; that they might go, and fall backward, and be broken, and snared, and taken
Isaiah 28.13.

I awoke a few minutes before the entry clock struck two—returned to bed in confusion of thought in consciousness awake, till I heard the Clock strike four— The intermediate hour of three having escaped my sense of hearing— I rose, repaired to my writing chamber, and saw Orion, Procyon, Sirius—the twins, and Venus as Morning Star. Took my shower and foot-baths, dressed and went up the hill; but the eastern horizon was bordered with haze intercepting the sight of the rising Sun, though within five minutes he peered out upon a clear sky.— Received yesterday

list.item: 8— Letter from John P. Foote corresponding Secretary of the Cincinnati Astronomical Society with six bound copies of my Oration delivered before that Society 10— Novr 1843.

9— Letter from S. E. Guild, Secretary of the Alumni Association of Harvard College 4 Court Street Boston 2. Septr. 1846. notifying me of my re-election as President of the Association for the current year—
10. Printed pamphlet Introduction to the Art of Elocution, by G. Vandenhoff— Lecture delivered 15— March 1846 at New-York.

11. Letter from Alvan Lamson D.D. Dedham 31. August 1846—enclosing one to him from Revd. Dr S. Gilman of Charleston S.C. with a manuscript Memorial of Atkinson Academy and RevdPeabody, and his wife my aunt—

div.p: Everyone of these papers would require a written return from me, if it were in my power— I shall probably be unable duly to notice any one of them

This day I received a Letter from my old friend George Joy 19. John Street Pentonville, London 18. August 1846. brought by the Steamer—Britannia Captain Hewitt which arrived at Boston yesterday at Noon from Liverpool— She brought 165 passengers to Halifax and 99 to Boston— Among them Louis M’Lane the Minister of the United States at the British Court with his family. She made her passage in 16 days; but the Cambria which departed from Boston on the first of August, reached Liverpool in ten days and 16 hours the shortest passage ever yet atchieved— I rode this afternoon with my daughters Mrs John and Mrs. Charles with her infant Mary— We went to Milton and returned by the way of the quarries. Mr Jonathan Wild of Braintree was here again—inquiring concerning the state of the claim of his mother Deborah Wild, widow of Jonathan Wild a pensioner of the Revolutionary War— I was not able to tell him, my chest of papers and books not yet having arrived from Washington— I requested him to call again in about a fortnight, which he promised— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here—
5. I.55— IV. Fahrenheit 75 at Sunrise 5.29. Shower bath
For the Egyptians shall help in vain, and to no purpose; therefore have I cried concerning this, their strength is to sit still. Isaiah 30.7.
But the liberal deviseth liberal things; and by liberal things shall he stand.

I saw Venus Morning star— Orion, Sirius, and Procyon, but the Sun rose beclouded— One of the hottest of Summer days succeeded with the mitigation of a strong western breeze— My Son went into Boston in the train of Cars from South Braintree starting from the Quincy station at 7.40. A.M. I went with my Granddaughter Mary-Louisa in the Old Colony train from Plymouth which started from that town at 7.30— A.M. and should have reached the Quincy station at 9. but was twenty minutes belated— We passed the Neponset, Dorchester, and Savin Hill stations, and reached the depot in Boston opposite the United States Hotel at 10 minutes before 10. Mr Emmons was with us in the Cars— I walked with Mary Louisa to the riding School in Franklin Street where she was to take her lesson, and leaving her there proceeded to the counting house of Abbot and Amos Lawrence in Milk Street. I found Mr Abbott Lawrence there, and agreed to go with him next Wednesday to the Meeting of the Committee of the board of Overseers of Harvard University on the Observatory to Cambridge— The Meeting is to be at half past 2. P.M at University hall, where they are invited to dine and to take the afternoon for examining the Observatory— I agreed to go into Mr Lawrence’s house in Boston by One O’Clock P.M. and at half past one to go with him in his Carriage to Cambridge, and to return with him to Boston in time to take the Evening train of Old Colony railroad Cars for South Braintree to be landed at the Quincy station. I had no conversation with Mr. Lawrence upon politics, on which our views no longer harmonize— They have been disappointed in not receiving the large Frauenhofer Refractor from Munich, which was to have been delivered in Cambridge last June when it would have been duty free— They now only hope to receive it before the first of next December, after which it must come charged with an import duty of between five and six thousand dollars— From Mr Lawrence’s counting room I went to my Son’s office, where I met Mr Henry Wilson of Natick and Mr George Odiorne, who did not speak to me of the republication of my Letters on Antimasonry— I purchased a small Night lamp and lantern— Precisely at Noon, I met my son and Granddaughter at the Old Colony Railroad depot, and came out in 27 minutes to Quincy.— The Barouche and Albert Putnam were in waiting and took us home. I received a curious Letter from Dutee J. Pearce— After dinner I rode with my two daughters and little Mary round through Braintree— Charles and his wife here this Evening— Summer heat with a refreshing breeze.
6. III.35— IV: Fahrenheit 74 at Sunrise 5.30.
The wilderness, and the solitary place, shall be glad for them; and the desert shall rejoice, and blossom as the rose. Isaiah 35.1.
And the ransomed of the Lord shall return, and come to Zion with songs, and everlasting joy upon their heads: they shall obtain joy and gladness, and sorrow and sighing shall flee away 35.10.

Bishop Lowth and subsequent commentators consider the 34th. and 35th. chapters of Isaiah as a distinct prophesy, and a complete and beautiful poem apart from the rest of the book— They are immediately followed by the narrative of the invasion of the kingdom of Judah by Sennacherib, King of Assyria— Pope has made great use of this 35th. chapter of Isaiah in his Messiah.

Mr Lunt preached this morning from 1. John 3.2. [“]Beloved, now are we the Sons of God; and it doth not yet appear what we shall be: but we know, that when he shall appear, we shall be like him: for we shall see him as he is— 3. And every man, that hath in him purifieth himself, even as he is pure.”— We are the sons of God? how then is Jesus Christ the only begotten Son of God? He declared himself times without number to be the Son of God, and spoke of God always as my father— But he taught all his disciples to address God, in prayer as our father, and he habitually called himself the Son of Man— He was born of a woman, born under the Law, according to the narrative of the Evangelists nine months after the miraculous conception, and in the same manner as other children are born— But God is a Spirit, and it is in a spiritual sense only that God is the father of Jesus Christ, though not in the same sense that he is the father of all mankind— Jesus Christ suffered crucifixion, for declaring himself to be son of God and sent on a mission to mankind by his father and Christians have involved themselves in confusion? inextricable by making Jesus himself a God. The whole doctrine of Trinity in Unity, and of the God Man Jesus Christ is a mass of absurdities as revolting to my intellect as the whole fabulous Pantheon of the Grecian Mythology. The apostle in Mr Lunts text of this morning admits that it doth not yet appear what we shall be— The state of the human soul after death is yet a mystery— It was so to St. John after the Resurrection and Ascension of Jesus— It was equally so to St. Paul whose description of the Judgment day and his distinction between the corruptible, and incorruptible body, leaves us precisely where we were— In the afternoon Mr Lunt preached from 1 Corinthians 15.15. Yea, and we are found false witnesses of God because we have testified of God that he raised up Christ; whom he raised not up, if so be that the dead rise not? The subject was a sequel to that of the morning discourse. Mr Lunt observed that the resurrection of Jesus Christ was the most important of all the tests of the truth of the Christian Religion and he delivered an elaborate argument in support of the Resurrection, by adducing sundry analogies in the successive changes in physical nature by alternations of life and death, in the mutations of corporeal substances— This was the hottest day of the Season; the Sun poured forth one continuous blaze throughout the day— I saw him set from the Northern porch of my Son’s house at 6.21— He and his wife were afterwards here.
7. III.30— IV. Fahrenheit 74 at Sun rise 5.31.

[“]Comfort ye, comfort ye my people, saith your God. Isaiah 40.1.— The voice of him that crieth in the wilderness, Prepare ye the way of the Lord, make straight in the desert a highway for our God. 4. Every valley shall be exalted, and every mountain and hill shall be made low: and the crooked shall be made straight, and the rough places plain 5. And the glory of the Lord shall be revealed, and all flesh shall see it together; for the mouth of the Lord hath spoken it.”

This is the transcendent prophesy of the mission of John the Baptist, and of the Advent of the Saviour, and as such expressly recognized by all the four evangelists. It is difficult to imagine, and much more to believe the connection between the prophesy and its fulfilment— At the time when the prophet wrote the kingdom of Israel had been conquered by the king of Assyria Tilgath Pileser, and the ten tribes dispersed no one knows where— Sennacherib second successor of Tilgath Pileser was then invading Judea and besieging Jerusalem. This invasion failed, but the prophet even then foretold the approaching destruction of the kingdom of Judah and the Babylonian captivity— So little apparent connection is there between the historical condition of the kingdom of Judah at that period, and the advent and personal biography of Jesus Christ that it requires a profound investigation of Chronology to bring the two periods into any relation with each other— The old testament closes with the extinction of the kingdom of Judah—with an interval of 70 years and a restoration of the Jews to the city of Jerusalem, and the rebuilding the temple under the direction of Ezra and Nehemiah— The next step brings us per saltum, to the birth of Jesus Christ at Bethelem in Judea, a Roman Province under the dominion of Augustus Caesar— In the mean time they had been successively subdued by Egyptian and Grecian Princes, successors of Alexander of Macedon, and were then governed by Herod a despotic monarch, and Caiaphas a high-priest— What possible relation was there between this state of things and the prophesy of the Messiah by Isaiah?

I received this day 1. A Letter from Charles Sumner, Boston. 2— Fisher’s National Magazine 3. George H. Colton’s American Review N. 21 all for September. 4. W. H. Chase pamphlet on fortifications 5. Wiley and Putnam’s Literary News-Letter Vol 5. N. 58— 6. B. B. French—Register of Cadets June 1846. 7. Sundry Patent Office Documents and sundry Newspapers. My daily supply for reading— I dined with my Son on the hill. His wife’s brother Sidney Brooks was there— He came out from Boston, and returned by the Railway Cars— He returns to-morrow or the next day, to New-York where he now resides.
8. II.50— IV. Fahrenheit 70 at Sunrise 5.32.

A bruised reed shall he not break, and the smoking flax shall he not quench: he shall bring forth judgment unto truth— Isaiah 42.3— till he send forth judgment unto victory— Matthew 12.20— Instead of smoking flax the Septuagint has it a dimly burning taper— This is one of the prophesies of the old Testament expressly said in the New to have been fulfilled in the person of Jesus Christ. I awoke ten minutes before 3. and returning to bed lay sleepless till my patience was exhausted waiting for the clock to strike four— Weary of waiting I left my bed, and the Clock struck as I was passing through the entry to my Library— I saw Orion, Sirius, Procyon, and Venus as Morning Star— I took a pleasant shower bath, dressed and on the hill saw the Sun at 5:32— Another day of intense unrelenting heat. Mrs Anne Taylor, widow of Brigadier General Taylor of this town, came, in trouble, with a statement that her son, Charles Taylor a young man who for the last two years has resided at Philadelphia, has been convicted and sentenced for a crime of which she said he was not guilty— I enquired what the crime was—she said Rape, which of course made it difficult for me to talk with her on the subject. She had no copy of the indictment, the verdict or the sentence; all she knew was that he was not guilty of the crime— A Petition had been presented to the Governor of Pennsylvania, she apparently knew not from whom for his pardon, and the Recorder had told them that if I would interpose the pardon would probably be granted. I wrote a Letter to the Governor of Pennsylvania, stating the application of Mrs Taylor to me, and that in consideration of the great respectability of her character and the reputation hitherto unsullied of her family, I had complied with her request.

Vinton John Adams— There was a light and partial Thunder shower this afternoon during which the Revd Mr Vinton was here, a clergyman who after several temporary settlements in this State and Maine is now casually living in New Hampshire— He claims to be descended from John Alden, and his granddaughter Hannah Bass, my great grandmother and made enquiries concerning the family of Vinton which I was not able to answer.— We consulted Farmer’s Register and the list of early settlers in Savage’s edition of Winthrop’s journal in neither of which the name is found.— There is but one of the name in the Catalogue of Harvard College—Benjamin Vinton 1795. and star’d. Mrs Taylor came again this afternoon, and I gave her the Letter to the Governor of Pennsylvania, which I had written at her request. The atmosphere was cooled by the thunder shower, and the Summer closed after four days of heat as intense as I ever witnessed.
9. II.45— IV. Fahrenheit 56 at Sunrise 5.33 Shower bath
That saith of Cyrus, He is my shepherd, and shall perform all my pleasure: even saying to Jerusalem, thou shalt be built: and to the temple, thy foundation shall be laid Isaiah 44.28.

This prophesy is said to have been delivered 712 years before Christ. The birth of Cyrus was 599 and his death 529 years before Christ— The prophesy therefore names Cyrus 113 years before he was born— The proclamation of Cyrus for rebuilding the temple was 536 before Christ— The building of the temple was then commenced, but was soon after suspended by command of Artaxerxes until the second year of the reign of Darius—then resumed and finished 515 before Christ— But it was not until 457 before Christ, that Cyrus went to Jerusalem, and not till 445. that Nehemiah went up— There is much obscurity and perplexing uncertainty in the chronology of these books.

The first daily train of Cars from the Quincy depot of the Old Colony Railroad to Boston coming from South Braintree only, start 20 minutes before 8. A.M. the second is the train from Plymouth, which leaves that place at half past 7—and the Quincy depot at 9. I took this to day and reaching Boston at half-past 9 first visited my shaver Cadmus 222 Washington Street— He asked me if the gloves I wore were those upon which I wrote the verses he had read in sundry newspapers? I said they were the same— They were first published in a Baltimore paper, and have been copied into several others, but I have never seen them in print. I called upon Dr Frothingham and spent an hour with him— He asked me where the Latin line “Miraturque novas frondes et non sua poma” was to be found, I said in the Georgics of Virgil. He said he had sought for it there without success—but he got the volume of Hoyne’s Virgil containing the Georgics, and found it line 82 of the second Book— I asked him if he had Lowth’s translation of the Book of Isaiah, he said he had, and also that of professor Noyes, and promised to lend them both to me— I called at the Emancipator office, but Mr Leavitt was gone to Springfield— I passed to my Son’s Office 23. Court-Street where I saw Mr Charles Sumner and Mr Nathaniel Curtis— As the hour of one approached I walked to Mr Abbot Lawrence’s house, where I saw Mrs Lawrence, and Bishop Eastburn whom I had not seen before— At half past one, I went with Mr Lawrence in his Carriage to Cambridge— We alighted at the President’s house; and Mr Everett immediately accompanied us to the University Hall where we met Mr Robert Treat-Paine, Professors Walker and Pierce, Mr W. C. Bond and his Son George with whom we dined, and then visited the Observatory and received Reports from Professor Pierce and Mr Bond, which were read and I took with me— Mr Paine returned with Mr Lawrence and me to Boston, and after a call at Mr James H. Foster I came out from half past 6 to 7—in the last train of the day for South Braintree I found Albert and the Barouche in waiting, and came home—
10. II.45— IV. Fahrenheit 54 at Sunrise 5:35 Shower bath—

“How beautiful upon the mountains are the feet of him that bringeth good tidings, that publisheth peace; that bringeth good tidings of good, that publisheth salvation; that saith unto Zion, thy God reigneth!
Isaiah 52.7.

I received this day 1. A Letter from Henry S. Baird, Attorney at Law, Green Bay, Wisconsin Territory, informing me of the decease of George Boyd, husband of my wife’s sister Harriet, aged about 65. They were married at Washington on the 14th. of March 1805. and I was present at their marriage— They have had a chequered, and not fortunate life— She was an admirable woman— He was a man of generous heart and good principles, but upon whose head Imprudence drew down the calamitous consequences of vice. They removed in 1818 from Washington to Michillimackinac, and he was many years an Indian Agent under the Government of the United States— 2. A. Letter from Henry Gassett, Boston dated yesterday, proposing to furnish copies from my Letterbooks of papers of the anti-masonic controversy a republication of which is proposed. 3. From John G. Palfrey Secretary of the Commonwealth, three bound Volumes of Public Documents of this State, one of the House of Representatives, one of the Senate and one Executive prepared by the Secretary, all in the present year 1846— This afternoon three young Ladies named J. Adams, E. P. Trenchard M. M. Howens came with a subscription paper from an Association styling itself the Cold Water Army, proposing a Pic Nic to be held some day next week— They had a meeting last Saturday and chose this committee to report at an adjourned Meeting next Saturday, the time and place— The highest subscription was of one dollar and I added my name to the list, with a promise to attend if I can. I rode with Miss Louisa Smith, Mrs Charles and her child Mary, and my granddaughter Mary-Louisa round by the Railway-house, along by the quarries, to Braintree and over Penn’s hill homeward— I alighted at Gill the Stationer’s shop and purchased a shilling vial of Maynard and Noyes’s Ink; a supply of which for me is a prime necessity and my stock of powders for making the Article is exhausted— Mr Daniel Baxter called on me this day and spoke of the application to the Selectmen of Quincy for an immediate call of a Town-meeting for commencing the erection of a Schoolhouse as required by the donation of my father to the Town— He said Harvey Field had told him I was for having the Town-Meeting right off.— I said I should leave the Town entirely to their own discretion, and would suggest nothing that could bring on the town any charge. He said he thought the Town meeting for the next annual elections would be time enough for taking up this matter, in which I concurred— There was a primary meeting of whigs last evening at Boston.
11. III.45— IV. Fahrenheit 60 at Sunrise 5:36 Shower-bath—
Ho, every one that thirsteth, come ye to the waters, and he that hath no money; come ye, buy and eat; yea, come, buy wine and milk, without money, and without price Isaiah 55.1.

Mr Edward J Penniman, now a resident of Philadelphia, brought me a Letter of introduction from Josiah Randall of that City— Mr Penniman is a native of Braintree and comes now on a visit to visit his relatives in that and the neighbouring towns— The name of Penniman is very familiar to the memory of my childhood, and existed in numbers of various conditions in the North and middle precincts of old Braintree— It has now totally vanished from Quincy where it was not respectable, and whether any remnant of it is left in Braintree I am not informed— Mr Penniman’s visit to me was of mere curiosity— MrsDerby with her son Brevet second Lieutenant George H Derby came to present personally their thanks to me for the services which I have fortunately been able to render him— Mrs Derby is the daughter of a friend of my youth, Horatio Townsend, a fellow student with me in the Office of Theophilus Parsons at Newburyport in 1787–1788 and 1789—more than 30 years after this his daughter married a worthless man namedDerby, who at the time when I was a candidate for the Presidency, and about the time when this young man was born, was used as a tool against me by false and treacherous representations of conversations held by me with Mr Townsend nearly twenty years before—and which he pretended Townsend had told him— Townsend denied having told him any such thing but the slander had its run, and when Jackson’s Collector came into the custom house Derby obtained a petty office under him— He afterwards quarreled with his Masters of Jackson’s kitchen cabinet, and published one or more libels upon them. In the mean time he had deserted his wife and children, and left them to shift for themselves— In 1841. John Bell of Tennessee being Secretary of War, Mrs Derby wrote me a Letter, earnestly soliciting a warrant of Cadet at the West Point Academy for Son, and by the kindness of Mr Bell I obtained it from the appointments at large. He was admitted in June 1842, and was graduated last June 7th. on the roll of his Class. He was then assigned to the Ordnance department, but wrote to me intreating to be transferred to the Corps of topographical Engineers which I also obtained from the kindness of General Scott— I asked him where he was stationed— He said he had not yet received his orders but expected to receive them next week— In the afternoon Elizabeth C. Adams was here with Lieutenant George Thom, fresh from Washington and on the eve of returning there— I rode round to Milton and Braintree, with Mrs Charles and her infant daughter only. After we returned, Mr Thomas Loring was here, and I agreed with him to go on a fishing party to Cohasset next Tuesday week, the 22d if the weather should be fair, and if not, the first fair day afterwards. I received a note from Messrs Welch and Mann proprietors of the National Circus which came here for this day only to attend their exhibition, which I did with my granddaughter Mary-Louisa, and Charles two sons, Charles and Henry.
12. II.55— IV. Fahrenheit 66 at Sunrise 5.37. Shower-bath.
Is not this the fast that I have chosen? to loose the bands of wickedness, to undo the heavy burdens, and to let the oppressed go free, and that ye break every yoke? Isaiah 58.6.

I received from Edward Everett, President of Harvard University, the triennial Catalogue of 1845, and a pamphlet containing the Rules and Statutes of the Professorships in the University at Cambridge, a title page in my judgment exceptionable— It is so denominated in the Constitution of this Commonwealth, by which it was recognized as a University but was also styled Harvard College— The University of Cambridge is in England—and to avoid all misunderstanding as well as to render all due honour to the founders of our cradle of education, the name of Harvard University should invariably be applied to it— Mrs N. L. Frothingham called before dinner to see our Ladies. She came out in the Railway Cars with her two daughters at noon, dined at her Sister’s, and returned to Boston with the train of 5. PM. Mary Louisa went to Boston at 9. took her lesson at the riding school, and returned with the Cars at Noon— In the assortment of my papers, my progress is backward rather than forward I answered the Letter of Henry S. Baird at Green Bay communicating information of the death of Mr Boyd— This volume of copies of my Letters is missing, and I know not where to look for it— I felt this afternoon the necessity of commencing the Report of the Committee of the Board of Overseers of the University, upon the Observatory—but entered upon it with so little spirit that I almost despair of ever finishing it.— I merely read the reports to the Committee of Professor Peirce, Perkins professor of Astronomy and Mathematics; and of William Cranch Bond, Observator—and wrote the introductory sentence of the Report of the Committee— I find that in the pamphlet sent me by President Everett of Rules and Statutes of the Professorships in the University of Cambridge there is no notice of the Perkins professorship of Astronomy and Mathematics. In the second volume of Quincy’s history of Harvard University pages 392. 566 and 637—all the proceedings for the construction and establishment of an Astronomical observatory until the publication of that work in 1840 are contained, and in page 430 is noticed the bequest of James Perkins at his death in August 1823 to the President and fellows of Harvard College of 20000 dollars for the purpose of founding such a professorship, as they with the consent of the Overseers of the College should judge most useful to the university and the public—a Question remains, how and when it was decided that the Perkins professorship should be a professorship of Astronomy and Mathematics— This is a lacuna or gap to be filled up in preparation for the report of the Committee: and there is another for the measures in process of execution to procure a Frauenhofer Refractor of the largest size— I received from Dr Frothingham Lowth’s translation of Isaiah, and the first volume of professor Noyes’s translation of the bible prophets including Isaiah; which will furnish me with occupation enough till next winter— I went up the hill to see the Sun set but he went down in a thick cloud

In the year 1841. George Brown then of Beverley and a stranger to me, but since then sometime Commissioner of the United States at the Sandwich Islands wrote me a Letter requesting me to versify in English this passage of the book of Isaiah, which I did and the lines were published by him in some Newspaper. A day or two since I looked for them among my papers—but found them not, and I know not where to search for them.

Mr Lunt preached this morning from 1. Chronicles 16.37. [“]So he left there before the Ark of the covenant of the Lord, Asaph and his brethren to minister before the ark continually as every day’s work required” And 1. Peter 2.5. “Ye also, as lively stones, are built up a spiritual house, an holy priesthood, to offer up spiritual sacrifices acceptable to God, by Jesus Christ.” Mr Lunt appears to have a fondness for double texts, taking one from the old and the other from the New testament— His object was to illustrate them one by the other— But the verse from the Chronicles is the institution by David of the great musical establishment by David, in the worship before the Ark of the Covenant, when he brought it up from the house of Obed-Edom and placed it in a tent, preliminary to the building of the Temple— The history of this establishment of Music vocal and instrumental, as forming a part of the daily service of divine worship is highly interesting, but was not noticed by Mr Lunt— The instruments named in the common English Bible are (ch 13 v. 8) Harps, Psalteries, timbrels, cymbals and trumpets— [(]ch. 15. v 28.) cornet— Psalm 98 Shawms. Daniel 3.4. Sackbut, flute and dulcimer— Thomson’s Septuagint calls Psalteries and Harps Nablas and kinyras— But there is little connection between this institution for the daily religious concert of music, by David, and the exhortations of Peter, to all his disciples, converts to Christianity to become an holy priesthood to offer up spiritual sacrifices— Yet the analogy between them is not unnatural— In the afternoon Mr Lunt’s sermon was from 1. Thessalonians 1.5. [“]For our gospel came not unto you in word only, but also in power, and in the holy Ghost, and in much assurance.” The argument was upon the miracles performed by Jesus Christ and the Apostles, considered as evidences of the truth of Christianity— Towards evening I rode with my Son down to Ex President Quincy’s, and found him at the old family mansion, to which he has returned for a Summer family residence. I inquired about the papers which passed between us last Summer relating to the Observatory at Cambridge— He said he had them all and would send them to me— On my return home I found P. P. F. Degrand here, who soon returned to Boston.

div.p: I executed with my wife a warranty deed of my house in Hancock Street Boston tofor 8300. dollars, witnessed by P. P. F. Degrand, and my Son— I had purchased it in 1806 of Isaac Davis for 6000 dollars. I received this day with the daily Boston Newspapers, Atlas Courier and Daily whig, and the National Intelligencer from Washington Littell’s living age N. 122 and a pamphlet of 86 pages 8vo. being a Statement of the controversy between Lewis Tappan and Edward E. Dunbar— These daily Newspapers and pamphlets furnish reading from day to day so copious and absorbing of time, that it leaves little or none for writing or for reading of permanent interest—day after day slips imperceptibly away, and nothing useful is atchieved— This afternoon Mr Charles Sumner, and Dr Howe came out from Boston, and invited me to attend, and preside at a public Meeting proposed to be held at Boston, a week from to-morrow Tuesday the 22d of this month, with a view to pass Resolutions expressing the public feeling at the recent kidnapping and abduction of a negro man who had escaped from his master at New-Orleans and landed in the neighbourhood of Boston— He was pursued, captured and ship’d off for New Orleans, by the Captain of the vessel in which he made his escape, unknown to the captain— But for retaking him the Captain had no authority from the owner of the Negro. There was a meeting last evening of a few persons indignant at this outrage upon the Laws of the Commonwealth and upon the rights of human nature, who resolved to call a public meeting, and these gentlemen came out as a Committee from this primary meeting to give me the invitation— After expressing my sense of the honour done me, I suggested some difficulties, owing to the state of my health, and especially the near extinction of my voice, disqualifying me, if not from attending at least from presiding at such a meeting, I finally promised to attend the meeting if my health would permit; and to preside, if I should be able to rely upon my voice for a hearing— From my house the Gentlemen went up the hill to my Son’s but he was out for a Sea bath, and they did not see him— Mrs John and Mrs Charles went to Boston, this afternoon, and came back at 9 this Evening with my granddaughter, Louisa Catherine, who finally comes home from Mrs Sedgwick’s school at Lenox, where she has passed two years in the course of her education. She was 15 on the 13th. of last Month—

The day commenced with a continuation of Summer heat, beclouded. About 9 in the morning there was a light shower of rain, immediately after which the wind came round to the Northwest, with a clear sky, and autumnal cold increasing through the day, the bright sun notwithstanding— I rode this afternoon with Mrs John and Mrs Charles and little Mary to Weymouth— We stop’d at Mr Minott Thayer’s house but he was not at home. I requested his niece to inform him that in calling to pay my respects to him, I had intended also to remind him that some years since (19 May 1841) Mr Asa French and Mr Benjamin V. French in behalf of the inhabitants of Braintree had borrowed of me a volume, being a copy made by my father’s direction for him, and left by him to me, of the original record of births marriages and deaths in the town of Braintree, from its first settlement in 1640.— The original itself was in the possession of the town Clerk of Braintree, but so mutilated and defaced, that he wanted my copy made some twenty years before to aid them in having a fair copy made for themselves—after which they promised to return mine to me— Upwards of five years have since passed away, and although I had occasionally missed the book I had almost forgotten the loan of it, till a few days since casually looking over my diary of 1841—I found in it the entry of this incident—the thousandth memento for me of the usefulness of keeping a diary— We visited also Mrs Mercy Tufts and her two unmarried daughters Susan and Mercy— Mrs Tufts is 83 years of age, and is confined to the house by the infirmities of age. At this time her bodily health is good and she lives cheerful and contented. We returned by the old County road over Penn’s hill which never fails to bring to my memory with a pleasing and tender melancholy the many walks over the same ground of my childhood from 1774 to 1778. when I first went to France— On my return home I found that Ex President Quincy had been here, and left the Papers relating to the Observatory at Cambridge which had passed between us in the Spring and Summer of 1845. These were all intended as preparatory materials and vouchers for a report of the Committee to the board of Overseers to be presented at their meeting during the Session of the Legislature in January 1846. The decline of my health towards the close of the Summer, and through the autumn of 1845 disabled me for the composition of the report, and none was made at the winter Session— The same Committee was continued for the present year and on my return from Washington last Month I found the subject precisely where we had left it this time last year— In the meantime the whole subject had so far faded upon my memory that I am more unprepared for writing the report to the overseers than I was then and although my health is partially restored, I am in deep concern for the perseverance and energy my only hope of which is in the passage from holy writ on the next page—

div.p: Morning visit from the Revd. Dr John Pierce of Brookline, with Mr Littell, the publisher of a weekly pamphlet of 48 large 8vo. pages selected from 22 English periodical magazines and Reviews, forming a continual exposition of the current literature of the English language— He brought with him and gave me the 123d. number of this compilation, dated 19. September 1846.— It has already been continued upwards of two years, and he has sent me a complete series of the preceding numbers— He wrote to me last December requesting my opinion upon the character of his undertaking to which I returned a favourable answer—which he publishes on the cover of every successive number— The price of this work is only 12 1/2 cents for each number and 13 numbers form a volume of 620 pages. Mrs Frothingham and Mrs Everett were also here before dinner, and dined with their sister on the hill— I walked up there, and found beside them a young lawyer namedAdams, who keeps an Office in Boston, N. 23. Court Street opposite that of my Son— He returned to Boston in the Cars from Plymouth which should have reached the Quincy Station at 20 minutes past 5— O’Clock P.M. but did not till the Temple Clock struck 6— Mrs Frothingham and Mrs Everett had already departed in the Carriage of the latter, and I remained to see the splendid Sunset of a cloudless sky at 8 minutes past 6— Charles and his wife and daughter Louisa Catherine passed the evening here— I have not yet taken firm hold of the papers relating to the Observatory, but am idling away hour after hour upon questions what were the musical instruments mentioned in the Old Testament, and how far they agree with those of modern times— It is said Genesis 4.21. that Jubal son of Lamech was the father of all such as handle the harp and organ— The Hebrew words are kinnar and hugab— The first a stringed and the second a wind instrument— The words in the Septuagint are ψαλτέριον και κιθάραν translated by Charles Thomson psaltery and kithara. The french protestant bible of Ostervald has le violon et les orgues, and the German Bible of Luther has die Geiger und Pfeifer— In Exodus 15.20 Miriam is said to have taken a timbrel in her hand, which the Septuagint calls τυμπανον and Thomson translates timbrel— Silver trumpets. Numbers 10.2— The Septuagint calls them σαλπιγγας— Ram’s horn Trumpets Joshua 6. I consulted the English translation of Calmet’s Dictionary in the third volume of which among the fragments illustrating scripture, p. 337. &c is an Article on Musical Instruments, and three plates with nearly thirty engraved representations of antient musical instruments among which a harp from Herculaneum, and two other specimens of harps closely resembling the modern forms of that instrument. But after all it is admitted that there is no certainty what was the form of any one of the musical instruments mentioned in the old Testament

div.p: Mr Johnson came out from Boston with Mr Lothrop the Minister of Brattle Street Church— Mr Whitney is the projector of a Railroad from Lake Michigan to the pacific Ocean, about which I had several conversations with him during the late Session of Congress— On the 31st. of July last Sidney Breese of Illinois, chairman of the Committee of the Senate on the public Lands presented to the Senate, a Report, in favour of this project, and a bill to set apart a portion of the public lands with which to construct a railroad from Lake Michigan to the Pacific Ocean— The adjournment of Congress on the 10th. of August suspended all further action upon this report and bill, and the subject will come up again for consideration in both houses at the approaching Session— Mr Whitney left with me copies of Senator Breese’s report and bill, which he requested me to read, and I promised him I would— Mr Johnson dined with us— Mrs Charles went to Medford to spend the day at her father’s— Charles went with her— Mary-Louisa went in the Cars to Boston, took a lesson at the riding School and returned to dine— After dinner, my wife and Mary went to Boston in the Carriage to meet and come home with Charles and his wife returning from Medford— Mr Johnson went with them to Boston, proposing to return to-morrow to New-York It was half past eight this Evening when my wife and Mary, with Charles and his wife returned from Boston, in the Carriage— Charles’s son John Quincy had returned from the Latin School, by the Cars at 7— Thomas Dumphy departed this day on his returning to Washington— Before he went, I settled with him, and paid him 45 dollars in full for two and a half months service as Coachman— I received this afternoon a Letter from Dr. Howe notifying me that they had been unable to obtain the use of Faneuil Hall for the public meeting on what is called the Slave case until next Thursday Evening the 24th. but still urging my attendance, which I answered promising to attend if possible— I received also a Letter from Samuel M. Chisom, Portland Septr. 15. requesting an autograph and a Letter from Joseph M. Edmonds, Portsmouth New-Hampshire Septr. 14. inviting me to deliver the opening lecture for the coming Season before the People’s Lyceum in that place— The Report to the Board of Overseers is not yet in embryo. div.p: Dr Frothingham preached at the Temple this morning from 2. Chronicles 15.15—last clause of the verse “and the Lord gave them rest round about.” This text lead to the expectation of a discourse upon the blessings of Peace, and the comforts of tranquility to Nations—but after a general allusion to the bearing of the text upon that condition of human Society, and remarking how happy the lot of ever Nation must be in the enjoyment of rest all about, Dr. Frothingham said that the Sentiment of the text was quite as applicable to individuals as to Nations, and that he should confine his consideration of it to that view of its Operation— He then enlarged upon rest all about as essential and indispensable to the well-being of man, and pointed out the various sources from which rest round about must be derived— The Greek and Roman philosophy upon the blessing of rest is painted in Horace’s Ode to Grosphus 2.16. Otium Divos rogat impotenti Prensus Egaeo, and the Hebrews both of the Old and New Covenant regard rest as the consummation of all happiness in Heaven as well as on Earth. The Bible tells us that almighty God, after labouring six days in the creation of the world and of man, rested the seventh day and hallowed it— This was the institution of the Sabbath, and consecrated to religious sanctity the alternation of labour and repose as a condition of human existence embracing all its relations and dependencies.— Mr Frothingham made however no allusion to the Sabbath, and understood the words rest round about in this passage as imparting only a state of peace and quiet. He dined with us, together with my Son, and in the afternoon preached from 2 Chronicles 15.17—the last clause of the verse— “Nevertheless the heart of Asa was perfect all his days.” Mr Frothingham dwelt upon the sacred regard to truth in all the narratives of the Scriptures—noticing the plain simple manner in which they relate all the errors and vices and crimes of the most exalted personages of their histories exemplified in the persons of Adam, Noah, Abraham, David, Solomon and Asa himself. He explained the qualified sense of the word perfect as applied to the heart of Asa all his days; and noticed the exceptions of deviation from rectitude with which he is charged by the historian of the Chronicles himself. He cautioned his hearers also against the error of concluding that perfection of conduct necessarily follows from perfection of the heart— Mr Loring of Hingham was at Meeting this afternoon, and called here after the service. I agreed to go with him on a fishing party to Cohasset next Tuesday if the weather should be fair— Dr. Frothingham with Charles and his wife and we had visits from George T. Bigelow, and John P. Hale of New Hampshire— Also from Mrs Stebbins, with Isaac Hull Adams, and his Sister Elizabeth— Sunset at 6.1—

list.item: Wood Henry—

div.p: Mr Henry Wood called on me this morning and enquired if I had among my papers the original Deed of agreement between the several proprietors of the lands overflowed by the Mill pond in this town to support the mill which was kept many years by William Veazie, and the Deed by which the lands were restored to their several original proprietors, when the Mill was abandoned— He wants it now for a suit at Law, which he has pending in the County Court at Dedham, against George Veazie for a portion of these Lands— I have some recollections of these deeds, and believe that I have them or copies of them somewhere among the private papers of my father, but I know not where they are— It has been the constant labour of my life to keep my books and papers in such systematic order that I may know where to find any one of them at five minutes notice, and for many long years I was enabled to do so with tolerable success—but I have now to go back for files and vouchers an documents of seventy years standing: during four several residences in Europe—in France, Holland, Russia, England, and Prussia, besides travels, in Spain, Germany Sweden and Denmark; and eight passages across the atlantic, and repeated navigations in the British Channel the North Sea and the Baltic in Europe, and in the Long Island Sound, the Northern Lakes and many of the rivers in America. I have passed successively through the conditions of a School boy, a student at Harvard University, and at Law in the Office of Theophilus Parsons. of a practicing Attorney and Counsellor—of a Secretary of Legation Minister Resident, Plenipotentiary and Envoy Extraordinary in five European Countries of Professor at Harvard University, member of the Senate of Massachusetts and of the Senate of the United States—8 years their Secretary of State—4 years their President, and now 15 years a member of their house of Representatives— My changes of residence have multiplied in proportion to the diversity of my occupations and I now pass twice at least every year from one to the other at 500 miles distance from each other— With all my papers, public and private vouchers, files of Letters, Letter-Books and Journals I have now the custody and care of those of my father, and they are falling into utter and inextricable confusion— I told Mr Wood I would look over my papers and see if I can find the deed for which he is searching— I received also a Letter form the Revd. Theodore Parker, enquiring for papers, which he says he sent me in July 1845. from Dr Flugel, Consul of the United States at Leipzig, and of which I had lost all recollection— I sent my answer to Mr Kellogg, declining to attend at the Cold water army Pic Nic tomorrow for previous engagement— Charles and his wife were here this evening.

div.p: I had agreed with Mr Loring, that I would be at his house at 7 O’Clock this morning to go upon a fishing party to Cohasset, if the weather should be fair— I rose as usual at 4. went through my usual lustrations frictions and dressing, except the cold shower bath— The wind was at North-east, the sky heavily beclouded, with every aspect of a coming storm— So it continued till after breakfast. At 6 O’Clock when I intended and had prepared to start for Hingham the whole firmament still threatened a tempest— I walked round the railway square, and saw no relaxation of the atmosphere— Breakfasted at 8 and the firmament began to soften its frown;—after 9 it was apparent that the clouds were dispersing and late as it was I ordered out Albert and the Carriage, and started for Hingham— I had barely crossed the railway bridge near my gate when I met Mr Loring in his chaise with a present of two fine mackrel, and a box of Seek no further Apples— He said there had been a heavy gale of wind off the coast last night and the surf on the beach this morning was so boisterous, that it was impossible to get the boat in which we were to embark for fishing out from her moorings. So that our fishing party must be postponed to some future day, and if I had gone to Hingham as I had proposed this morning we still should not have been able to go out— Mr Loring proceeded to Boston, and was succeeded here by an Old man named James Ward a claimant of a pension for services during the revolutionary War in the Deane frigate, and at the battle of White Plains— He had been here on theof last Month, and referred me to Elias Hasket Derby Esqr. Justice of Peace in Boston, who had heretofore had charge of his papers, and transmitted them to the Pension Office at Washington but had obtained nothing— This was confirmed by Mr Derby to whom I applied at his office on the— Ward says that the pension due to him, he believes has been obtained by a man named Stephen Ward fraudulently in as much as he Stephen Ward was not born at the time of the battle of White Plains— I told him that as I knew not the reasons why his claim for a pension had been disallowed I saw nothing that I could do for him but upon my return to Washington to represent his case to the Commissioner of Pensions which I promised to do— In the meantime I advised him to have a petition or written statement of his claim drawn up, and furnished to me to take with me, and he promised that he would— The weather cleared up bright and I rode in the barouche with my daughters and the child— There was a whig meeting at Boston this Evening preliminary to the Convention for the nomination of Governor tomorrow—

div.p: I had a sleepless Night— Was up between two and three O’Clock of the morning—returned to bed, and lingered without repose till five when I rose for the day, with a sore throat, a voice nearly extinct, a redoubled agitation of nerves, and a tremor little short of absolute disqualification for writing. My Socratic demon, whispered to me authoritatively not to attempt to preside at the Meeting at Faneuil hall tomorrow evening upon the case of a Slave who had escaped from New-Orleans, in a merchant vessel from this State commanded by a Captain Hannum— The Slave had secreted himself in the vessel unknown to the Captain, and succeeded in a getting to land at South Boston Hannum pursued and found him there—seized him without warrant or authority of any kind—ship’d him onboard of another vessel bound to New-Orleans and sent him back to his Master— Attempts were made to follow the vessel in which he was ship’d with a writ of Habeas-Corpus but without success— The meeting in Faneuil Hall is called to ascertain the facts of the case and to consult upon measures to be taken for preventing the repetition of similar cases, and I had promised if possible to attend and preside at this meeting. I am disabled by the act of God, and was obliged to write to my Son, requesting him to give notice of the fact to Dr Howe, and Mr Charles Sumner, the Committee who had given me the invitation— Unfortunately my Letter to my Son was not sent— The Convention of the whigs for the nomination of Governor and Lieutenant Governor of the Commonwealth for the year 1847. was held this day at Faneuil Hall, and George N. Briggs was unanimously nominated for re-election as Governor, and John Reed as Lieutenant Governor. A set of Resolutions prepared by Daniel Webster was adopted, and another offered by Stephen C Phillips was rejected— There are two divisions in the party, one based upon public principle and the and the other upon manufacturing and commercial interest— I had a morning visit form Mr Lunt, and confined myself to the house for the day. I make no progress in the Report of the Committee of the Overseers upon the Observatory and am even diverted by debility from the searching examination of the papers upon which the report must be founded. I received this day a note from President Edward Everett proposing the immediate publication of W. C. Bond’s Report and Observations which the American Academy have offered to have performed; upon which it will be necessary for me to consult Mr Abbott Lawrence. I received also a Letter from Edward C Delavan Ballston Centre Septr 15 1846. with a pamphlet containing ten Lectures by Dr Eliphalet Nott President of Union College Schenectady on the use of intoxicating liquors—which he requests me to read and of which he proposes to have numberless copies published in Stereotype

5 Then they said to Jeremiah, The Lord be a true and faithful witness between us, if we do not even according to all things for the which the Lord thy God shall send thee to us 6 Whether it be good, or whether it be evil, we will obey the voice of the Lord our God to whom we send thee; that it may be well with us, when we obey the voice of the Lord our God. Jeremiah 42.5.6.

This is one of the passages illustrative of the fundamental principle of the Hebrew Religion, Politics and Morals— Obedience to the will of God, whether good or evil was sure to be rewarded with prosperity—and this will of God was to be revealed to them by the prophet whom they sent to God, to learn his will. The will of God, revealed to the prophet’s ear by the word to his eye in vision, or to his Memory in a dream, was the summum bonum for which the Grecian philosophers made such long, painful, and fruitless research— Thomson’s translation from the Septuagint of this 6th. verse, reads—Whether it be agreeable, or disagreeable we will hearken to the voice of the Lord our God in respect to that for which we send thee to him that it may be the better for us.

I received this morning a Letter from Dr Howe again urging my attend at the Faneuil Hall meeting this Evening. I had a good night’s sleep last Night and this morning the sore throat had passed away—the hoarseness much subsided and the voice almost entirely recovered though still very feeble. Ever since the day when Dr Howe and Charles Sumner came with the invitation, and I had given them the conditional promise to attend, the notification of the meeting in all the daily newspapers had stated that it would be presided over by me— As this day advanced I felt returning strength and immediately after dinner I concluded to go at all hazards— I went up the hill, and found my Son who had been into Boston and returned, was with his family at dinner. Dr Bowditch came in soon after from Boston to request that I would write a note approbatory of the meeting to be read there and account for my absence— I told him I had concluded to go, and agreed to meet him at his house at 6 this Evening— I went accordingly with my Son, and found assembled at Bowditch’s house a small tea party of the gentlemen who had called the Meeting— At 7 we went to Faneuil Hall where a great crowd of people were assembled filling every nook and corner of the room, including numbers of ladies filling the galleries— The chair was assigned to me by acclamation. Stephen C. Phillips and Samuel May were chosen Vice-Presidents andAndrew Secretary to the Meeting. It continued till about ten in the Evening, sundry Resolutions were adopted with inconsiderable opposition. Among the Speakers was my Son, and when he rose I resigned the chair to Mr Stephen C. Phillips— The meeting closed with a vote of thanks to me moved by Edmund Quincy and carried not without opposition— With my Son I returned from the Hall to Quincy, and reached home after 11 at Night.

As I live saith the King, whose name is the Lord of hosts, surely as Tabor among the mountains, and as Carmel by the sea, so shall he come
Jeremiah 46.18.

div.p: I had a comfortable night’s rest, and slept this morning until near 5. at the striking of which by the Clock I rose—but my principal complaint hung by me all this day. Gibbon remarks in the Memoir of his own life, that the greatest discomfort of his old age was that in proportion as he advanced in years, the power of hope over his mind gradually declined— My principal annoyance in the decline of years is that I rise in the morning with thoughts occupied exclusively with concern for my health, and the encroachments of gradual decay—the flickering of the light in the socket.— We had a morning visit from Ex-President Josiah Quincy with his eldest Son’s wife, and his eldest daughter Miss Elizabeth Susan Quincy— Mr Quincy has returned for his Summer residence to the family mansion in this town which he inherited from his grandfather Coll. Josiah Quincy who built the house, after that in which John Hancock was born, and which he had purchased and dwelt in after the death of Hancock’s father the minister, was burnt. I say inherited; but it was bequeathed to him by his grandfather’s will, subject to the right of dower of his third wife Ann Marsh, who survived him. Coll. Josiah Quincy died in 1783 and his widow dwelt in the house, until after the marriage of the devisee in 1800, she by a composition of mutual agreement she relinquished it to him. He made it his summer residence for many years residing in Winter at Boston, until in 1829—being elected President of Harvard University he necessarily resided the year round at Cambridge— Having resigned that Office on the 1st. of October 1845, he returned to Boston for the winter, and to what the Revd. Mr Clark calls the Quincy hive for the Summer. His eldest Son Josiah junr is now Mayor of the city of Boston, and his wife prefers Nahant for a Summer residence to Quincy— But she is now on a visit to her beau-pere and belle mere— I read Dr Gilman’s reminiscences of New England at the close of the 18th. century, and especially of the Revd. Stephen Peabody of Atkinson New-Hampshire, and of his second wife my mother’s sister Elizabeth— If the protestant creed tolerated canonization, those two persons would have deserved to stand among the foremost on the Calendar. I read also Dr Lamson’s discourse in defence and support of the congregational form of worship— He extols it for its simplicity— I prefer it to the Roman Catholic which admits, and to the English Episcopal which seems to admit the power of the Priest to grant absolution for sins— But there is no Christian Church with which I could not join in social worship— I received a Letter from Misses Kilburn and Healy late of Boston, now keeping a boarding and day school for young Ladies at Baltimore, with their prospectus.
26. Fahrenheit 64. at Sunrise 5.52. Cloudy Clear. Heavy dew.
Cursed be he that doeth the work of the Lord deceitfully, and cursed be he that keepeth back his sword from blood. Jeremiah 48.10.

The prohibition of War, as a religious and moral principle belongs exclusively to the Christian dispensation, if indeed it is included in that— War so far from being discountenanced in the old testament is frequently commanded, and the total destruction of the Canaanitish Nations, was not only enjoined upon the children of Israel, but their disobedience to that command by sparing a remnant of the victims, was held and declared to be a crime for which their own destruction was doomed— For the same offence Saul forfeited his kingdom and his life, and here the prophet Jeremiah a captive in Chaldea denounces a curse upon every man who keepeth back his sword from blood—

div.p: The day slip’d again from under me.— I had seen in the ship news of yesterday’s Boson Newspapers, the welcome announcement of the arrival from Alexandria and Georgetown D.C. of the Schooner Forest king Captain Kelly, in which my chest of books and papers, with many other valuable articles had been ship’d— This day my son procured the delivery of them in Boston—they were brought out in the freight train of railway Cars, and landed at our own house this evening— The vessel was much out of time, and I had almost despaired of ever hearing from her more—especially after we knew she had sailed from Alexandria, there had been two destructive gales of wind on our coast fatal to great numbers of vessels— But Captain Kelley had evaded them by putting into Norfolk, and waiting there for fair weather.— My health is still unsettled, capricious and wavering— My nights restless and dispirited— I concluded my Letter to Dr. Alvan Lamson to return Dr Gilman’s Reminiscences, and to take friendly notice of the Discourse upon the Congregational mode of worship, which I have preferred to all ever since Dudley Atkins at Newburyport republished an old dialogue between a blacksmith and a student of divinity, to prove the super-excellence of the Church of England’s book of Common prayer— In my mind the blacksmith’s argument recoiled upon himself— Yet I have joined in worship with the episcopal church both in England and in this country, down to the present day, though without ever subscribing to the creeds of that church even as confined in this Country to the Apostle’s and the Nicene-creed, and discard in the Athanasian altogether. I rode this afternoon in the Coach with my two daughters and little Mary over Milton hill, and over the Bridge to a shop where Mrs Charles stop’d two or three minutes. On returning home we found Mr and Mrs Thomas P. Smith, with two small children a boy and a girl. Mrs Smith brought with her a beautiful bunch of flowers, and requested of me a contribution for a volume of miscellaneous essays which she is about to publish, and I promised to furnish one.

Thou art my battle axe and weapons of war: for with thee will I break in pieces the Nations; and with thee will I destroy kingdoms—
Jeremiah 51.20—

This is expressed with so much obscurity that it is not clear who is intended by the battle-axe— It may be Nebuchadnezzar—or Cyrus—or Jacob—or figuratively Christ— In the Septuagint—the energy of the image and the image and the image itself is lost— The Genevan French and Luther’s German translations substitute for the battle-axe a hammer, and as the battle-axe itself is a type of all possible weapons of aggressive War, to name it, followed by weapons of War generally without specification rather weakens the idea it would convey if it stood alone— But the battle-axe is a weapon far more terrific than a hammer.

The Revd. Joseph Henry Allen, a graduate at Harvard University of 1840, a grandson of my long cherished friend and sometime chum, not long since deceased, professor Henry Ware, now pastor of the third Congregational church of Roxbury at Jamaica Plains preached at the Temple this day, by exchange with Mr Lunt— His morning text was from Ecclesiastes 1.8. “All thing are full of labour, man cannot utter it: the eye is not satisfied with seeing nor the ear filled with hearing.” He drew from his text a parallel between the lives and characters of David and of Solomon— The father and the Son both persons of transcendent renown among the children of men Seated on the pinnacle of glory— Tarnished with the pollution of shame— Mighty Monarchs. Holy prophets, Sublime Poets, venerable sages— David from a stripling Shepherd’s boy, rising through the gradation of a minstrel page to Saul, a commander of his army, the husband of his daughter, a banished fugitive from his kingdom, and a leader of the Philistines—then Captain of a band of outlaws— King of the tribes of Judah and Simeon after the death of Saul, and then thirty three years king of all the tribes. Solomon receiving from him the kingdom as a bequest—reigning forty years; endowed with wisdom specially from heaven, prosperous and happy beyond all other men yet falling in his old age beguiled by fair idolatresses, into the foulest worship of the heathens— This parallel and contrast are deeply impressive and were well handled but might have more widely extended— Mr Allen dined with us and after dinner preached from Luke 10.29.—“And who is my neighbour?” This text naturally introduces the parable of the good Samaritan, of which Sterne has made such admirable use— Mr Allen barely alluded to it, and meddled not at all with the narrative— The subject embraces the origin and history of the feuds and divisions between the Jews and the Samaritans— I suppose them to have arisen as early as the elevation of Saul to the kingdom; and though smothered during his reign, and those of David and Solomon, broke out broke out and became perpetual, on the revolts of the ten tribes from Rehoboam under Jeroboam the Son of Nebat— I was present as a delegate from our Temple Church at the Ordination of Mr Allen at Roxbury on the 18th. of October 1843.

25. The Lord is good unto them that wait for him, to the soul that seeketh him— 26. It is good that a man should both hope, and quietly wait for the salvation of the Lord. 27. It is good for a man that he bear the yoke in his youth
Lamentations of Jeremiah— 3.25.26.27.

I am involving myself in scriptural enquiries beyond my depth and the possible consequences of which begin to discourage me in the pursuit—and absorb too much of my time— This conviction bears upon me especially since I have come to the reading of the prophets— From beginning on the first of last December to read every morning two chapters of the common English Bible without note or commentary, I have come to read four chapters every day—the corresponding chapters of Charles Thomson’s version of the Septuagint— Hewlett’s and Scott’s notes and commentaries—consulting occasionally Ostervald’s French and Luther’s German Bible, the translation of Calmet, and even the original Septuagint— I have barely touched upon Lowth’s Isaiah, and Noyes’s translation of the prophets— These have started multitudes of new questions that I cannot stop to investigate and I must discard, and give up the chase of the inaccessible mountaintops— The transpositions of the chapters of the Book of Jeremiah, as scrupulously followed by The Septuagint of Thomson is so perplexing that it is like a dislocation of all my limbs—

list.item: Newcomb George

div.p: I slept this morning till near four, and rose at that hour— The constellation of Orion shone full in the Meridian, with his outposts Procyon and Sirius— Venus rose after five hastening to her conjunction with the Sun and her station as evening Star. Before Sunrise I walked round the Railroad square but the Sun rose beclouded— My symptoms are convalescent, but my weakness still has the mastery over me. I did not cast a look over the Observatory papers, or write a line for the Report of the Committee— Mr George Newcomb was here this afternoon but I could give him no encouraging account of his Petition before the House of Representatives of the United States for the bounty upon his lost fishing Schooner Rosanna— I told him there had been no Report from the Committee to which the petition was referred, and promised I would give all possible, and proper attention to it if able to attend at the approaching Session of Congress. My Letter to Dr Lamson was despatched— I received from my friend Christopher Morgan, a former member of Congress from theCongressional District of New in a duodecimo pamphlet of 51. pages the Argument of William H. Seward sometime Governor of New-York in defence of William Freeman on his trial for the murder of a whole family named Van Nest, husband, wife and children The trial was at Auburn, where Mr Seward resides, on the 21st. and 22d. of last July— The defence was insanity, and on that ground the man was acquitted— I went up the hill, and from the Northern porch of my Son’s house Saw the Sunset at 5.47. My Son, and his wife, and their daughter Louisa Catherine spent a short evening here.
29. IV. Fahrenheit 40 at Sunrise 5.55.
As an Adamant, harder than flint, have I made thy forehead: fear them not, neither be dismayed at their looks, though they be a rebellious house.
Ezekiel 3.9.

Adamant. It is remarkable that this beautifully sonorous word, has in the English language has no definite meaning or rather has three distinct and separate meanings— It is an imaginary stone, harder than flint as in this passage of the common Bible— It is the diamond, and so called in the French and German translations of this passage. And it is the loadstone. The Septuagint does not name it— No progress with the Report to the Overseers on the Observatory. Quite convalescent from my late Sore throat and debility— Voice still somewhat hoarse— Barely returned my recent arrears of Journal— I have received 1. A Letter from Mr Frye Washington— 24 Septr. mentioning an application to purchase a site for an ice house on the margin of the mill pond of the Columbia Mills— This Letter must be answered. 2. A Letter from J. M. Elam Baton Rouge Louisiana Septr. 1846—enclosing a printed paper signed by him, proposing sundry questions concerning Texas and the Western boundary of Louisiana, upon which he desires me to give my opinion with regard to a line of boundary, such as the pretension of France could have urged, and he says that in order to sustain President Polk for sending an armed force on the Rio del Norte an appeal has been made to all I have ever said as to that rivers having been claimed by France as the Western limit of antient Louisiana— This Letter also should be answered; but no pretensions of France to the Rio del Norte, as the boundary of Louisiana could extend inland from the mouth of that river, which could itself be claimed only as a half way point from La Salle’s landing at the Bay of St. Bernard, and the small detachment which he left there when he went Northward in search of the Mississippi and was murdered on his way. Which detachment was exterminated within two years whether by Spaniards or by Indians has never been ascertained, and was never after heard of— Nor has it ever been proved where the spot of La Salle’s landing and Settlement was, the name of the Bay of St. Bernard not having been given by him— The appeal of Mr Polk’s partizans to my arguments in discussion with the Spanish minister in the Negotiation for the Florida Treaty is a dishonest subterfuge to escape from the obligation which fixed by solemn agreement of both parties the boundary line at the Sabine where it had been already fixed in 1805 by a military convention between General Wilkinson and the commander of the Spanish troops in Mexico— 3. A printed circular from L. V. Badger and Co. Boston advertising and recommending Leighton’s Patent Enema Chair— The word enema is not in Johnson’s nor in Webster’s Dictionary.— I did not know its meaning, and resorted to Rees’s Encyclopaedia where I found it. I saw the Sunset from the Northern porch of Charles’s house at 5.46— For he rises before 6 in the morning and sets before 6 at Night— My Son was here this Evening—

And behold, the man clothed with linen, which had the ink-horn by his side reported the matter, saying I have done, as thou hast commanded me.
Ezekiel 9.11.

This man clothed with linen and with an inkhorn at his side, is called in the Septuagint a man clothed in a long robe, and a girdle of sapphire about his loins— The clothing of linen is said by Scott to denote a Priest, and not a Soldier— The inkhorn may be of the same import, but Hewlett thinks the inkhorn out of place, and that ink was not used in those days; but how a man could be girt with a sapphire girdle is more questionable than that he should have an inkhorn at his side— In the vision of Ezekiel this man was charged with two distinct offices—the first was to set a mark upon the foreheads of the righteous persons who lamented and abhorred the crimes and corruptions of the people, and were therefore to be saved from the general destruction of the city: and this was what he reported he had performed: the second was to go in between the wheels and the Cherubim of the Sapphire throne, and fill his hand with coals of fire and scatter them over the city— He was at once a minister of Justice of Mercy, and of Vengeance—

We had a visit this afternoon from this Lady one of the three maiden daughters of my Mother’s cousin Quincy Thaxter of Hingham. I received a second Letter from Frederic Oxnard of Portland Maine Septr. 25. 1846. requesting an Autograph— I receive multitudes of such Letters from entire Strangers none of which I have answered for several years— I have not been without questions of the minor morals whether this course is perfectly right— In good fellowship and good neighbourhood, a civil request is entitled to a civil answer— But no one has the right to ask an autograph of an entire stranger, and the subscription of a name, which collectors of autographs generally desire, is liable to dangerous accidents, and to possible monstrous abuses— A discussion upon the right, would be useless, and exposed to ridicule so that I have consider the omission to answer such requests as a prudent and justifiable mode of declining to gratify them I am not however perfectly with my own conclusion— A request for an autograph from a stranger is an act of personal respect and kind feeling— It deserves return in the same spirit though not necessarily witch compliance— Were I not disabled for writing I would in every case comply, and in the omission to answer, my apology to myself is disability controuling my will. I received also a Letter from Daniel Adams of Keene New-Hampshire September 24. making enquiries of the genealogy of the Adams family, to ascertain whether he is consanguineous, as Sir Toby Belch says with us; but from the account he gives of himself he appears not to be a chip of the Old block— The Great Western Steamer arrived at New York in 17 days from Liverpool.
